image.altText: A message on an eftpos machine saying there is an issue and to check connection.

items.synopsis: Train lines came to a halt, cafes couldn't take payment, triple-0 calls didn't go through. The Optus outage was more than just an inconvenience for millions of Australians.

title.children: Over 10 million customers were affected by the Optus outage. Here's how it played out

image.altText: Debbie Hatumale-Uy standing in front of boxes stacked in a warehouse.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of thousands of businesses saw trade literally stall as the Optus outage put payment systems, internet services, phones and work-from-home set-ups out of action. Now, many are demanding compensation.

title.children: Businesses count the economic cost of Optus network meltdown

image.altText: Business meeting

items.synopsis: More than 800 large companies paid no tax in 2021-22, an Australian Taxation Office (ATO) report reveals. Here's the ATO's full list.

title.children: ATO reveals the more than 800 companies that paid no tax

image.altText: Anthony Albanese shakes hands with Xi Jinping in front of the Australian and Chiense flags in Beijing.

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese has managed to pull off a successful double act over the past fortnight with his visits to both Washington and Beijing, writes David Speers.

title.children: Albanese has pulled off a successful double act in the US and China — but what comes next?

image.altText: Hip hop group Dem Mob has won five awards at the annual SA Music Awards

items.synopsis: An ambitious decision to help a troubled outback teenager through music is capped by an Indigenous hip hop group cleaning up at this year's SA Music Awards.

title.children: Indigenous hip hop group Dem Mob scoops pool at awards night

image.altText: soldiers walk through an alleyway between buildings, rubble and debris lining the ground, one of the buildings is badly damaged

items.synopsis: Gaza City is encircled by tanks and the skies above are full of planes and drones. Now, after inching cautiously around its outskirts, Israeli ground troops are going in, writes Eric Tlozek.

title.children: Israel's campaign to destroy Hamas is kicking off. It faces two major problems

image.altText: smoke and a large explosion still burning rises into the sky

items.synopsis: Thousands of Palestinians have left their homes to move south as Israeli operations in the Gaza Strip intensified, continuing to strike areas in all parts of the enclave.

title.children: Palestinians flee their homes as Israel continues Gaza bombardment

image.altText: CCTV vision of two police officers standing next to a man on the ground.

items.synopsis: South Australian police release CCTV footage showing part of an incident that resulted in two officers being removed from operational duty while their conduct is investigated.

title.children: SA Police release vision of arrest after officers used taser, pepper spray at care home

image.altText: A woman and man both leaving court separately with their faces blurred.

items.synopsis: A trial is underway in the South Australian District Court for a former husband and wife who allegedly had sex with their underage employee who worked at their family-owned bakery in regional SA in the 80s.

title.children: Former couple accused of having sex with underage employee at bakery in regional SA

image.altText: Jodi Wilson, with short black hair and neutral expression, stands holding small child, seen from the back, surrounded by trees..

items.synopsis: When life wasn't quite working for Sydney parents of four Jodi and Daniel, they decided to take a road trip. It proved to be a life-changing act.

title.children: Jodi and her partner spent their house deposit on a family holiday. It changed their lives

image.altText: A sandstone window with yellow "yes" writing and an Optus sign.

items.synopsis: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin says "a technical network fault" is to blame for the company's nationwide outage on Wednesday, but can't provide more information on the cause before conducting a deeper analysis.

title.children: Optus defends 'front-footed' communication with customers after 'technical network fault'

image.altText: The outside of a telecommunications store.

items.synopsis: The South Australian premier describes the Optus outage as the single biggest telecommunications outage seen in Australia and says he believes most governments are affected in some form.

title.children: Mental health triage services impacted in South Australia by Optus outage

image.altText: A swing with a blue rope tied to it with a blurred house in the background

items.synopsis: More than 100,000 online and telephone reports were made to SA's child abuse line last financial year, a 9 per cent increase from the year prior.

title.children: SA faces ‘public health emergency’ due to rise in suspected child neglect, minister warns

image.altText: A checklist graphic with crosses and a tick and a measuring tape on one side and hammer on their other

items.synopsis: Here's some steps you can take to help identify the risky players – they're not flawless, but they are (mostly) free.

title.children: How to spot a risky home builder who might not be around to finish the job

image.altText: A composite of an old photo and an album cover of the same photo in colour hung on a wall

items.synopsis: A music industry mystery is solved — by a researcher who stumbled across an old photo and a familiar face in a museum album.

title.children: Museum says after half a century it has uncovered the identity of the man on Led Zeppelin's most successful album

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair wearing a blazer stands in front of greenery.

items.synopsis: A year after a cyber attack exposed the personal details of millions of Optus customers, the telco boss is on another apology tour. She seems to have learned nothing, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Can Optus boss Kelly Bayer Rosmarin survive another debacle?

image.altText: a man kneels beside a tent.

items.synopsis: Adam "Angel" Nieto has been living on the streets for 30 years. Now a run-in with the law has a social support service calling for better treatment of homeless people.

title.children: Homeless man on assault charges after wielding pick axe during eviction from makeshift campsite

image.altText: Mark Regev stands at a pdoium

items.synopsis: A senior adviser to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Mark Regev, says the country's military will have a presence in Gaza after the Israel/Hamas conflict ends.

title.children: Netanyahu adviser says Israel will require 'fluid' military presence in post-war Gaza

image.altText: a large box full of brown and white bars of soap with minor signs of use

items.synopsis: A Melbourne program is recycling millions of used soap bars from hotels, cleaning it and turning it back into bars ready to be donated to people in need.

title.children: This organisation is taking used hotel soap and 'doing something wonderful with it'

image.altText: An inflatable pool with a blow up ring floating in it

items.synopsis: A Perth woman who held the heads of both her young children underwater in an inflatable pool is jailed, and banned from ever contacting them again.

title.children: Perth mother jailed after holding children's heads underwater in blow-up pool

image.altText: A Tasmanian tiger stands in an enclosure.

items.synopsis: New research disputes a recent hypothesis the last captive Tasmanian tiger was a female, and argues the animal did not die from neglect.

title.children: Thylacine researchers take aim at recent 'last Tasmanian tiger' theory

image.altText: Two South Asian women dressed in traditional Indian clothing

items.synopsis: This month, celebration is in the air for millions of Hindus, Sikhs, Jains and Newar Buddhists across the world who are observing Diwali — the Festival of Lights. But what about those who aren't religious?

title.children: Can you celebrate Diwali if you're not religious? These Indian Australians do it to feel closer to their culture

image.altText: Composite of a man in army fatigues next to a blown up car

items.synopsis: Ukraine says it carried out a "special operation to eliminate" Mikhail Filiponenko, working "jointly with representatives of the resistance movement."

title.children: Ukraine's spy agency admits to car bomb killing of Russia-backed politician

image.altText: Composite image of two young men, with police behind them.

items.synopsis: A man who lit bushfires and filmed videos pledging his loyalty to Islamic State is found guilty of terrorism-related offences, but his older brother will walk free after being cleared by a jury.

title.children: Jury delivers mixed verdicts to Melbourne brothers accused of terrorism over small bushfires

image.altText: Ben Stokes and Chris Woakes shake hands at the Cricket World Cup.

items.synopsis: Amid a disastrous defence of its men's Cricket World Cup title, England salvages a degree of pride to lift itself off the bottom of the team standings in India.

title.children: England snaps five-match losing run at World Cup as Stokes belts century against the Netherlands

image.altText: A sign saying "caution" in front of an open pit coal mine and power station.

items.synopsis: The gap between climate rhetoric and fossil fuel use is growing, according to a UN report that warns the world's carbon budget has almost been used up.

title.children: Climate disconnect grows wider as fossil fuel use soars to 'double' required level by 2030

image.altText: A close up shot of crocodile teeth, with brown stains on them

items.synopsis: Northern Territory cattle producer Colin Deveraux knows he is lucky to be alive after being attacked by a 3.2-metre saltwater crocodile.

title.children: 'He shook me like a rag doll': Cattleman survives croc attack by biting back

image.altText: Muslim woman wearing a white hijab, red shirt and black jacket, sitting in her home.

items.synopsis: Hanaa Elmobayed was one of 19 Australians who made it out of Gaza through the Rafah crossing with Egypt last weekend. But there were many times the mother of five feared she'd never make it back to her family.

title.children: Hanaa was visiting her mum in Gaza when the war broke out. Now home, she's scarred from what she saw

image.altText: A woman uses her phone outside an Optus store as a man looks at his.

items.synopsis: Canada, Japan, and the United States are among the countries that expect service providers to implement roaming capabilities to cover major network failures.

title.children: Why can't customers be automatically switched to other carriers when their network goes down?

image.altText: A group of young and middle-aged women cheer and clap in a crowded room.

items.synopsis: Democrats win control of both legislative chambers in Virginia, while in deep-red Kentucky, Democratic governor Andy Beshear is re-elected to a second four-year term.

title.children: Ohio voters enshrine right to abortion in state constitution, Democrats score wins across other US states

image.altText: Aerial view of Boigu community surrounded by the ocean to the top, green vegetation and water holes below

items.synopsis: Legal and climate experts liken rising sea levels and climate harms to “colonisation” as proceedings for the Australian Climate Case resume.

title.children: Further climate change inaction 'cultural genocide' for Torres Strait, experts say

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a suit with grey hair and glasses stands behind a podium.

items.synopsis: The 335-year-old insurance market apologised in 2020 for its role in facilitating the 18th- and 19th-century slave trade.

title.children: World’s largest insurance market to invest millions of dollars into former slave trade regions

image.altText: High Court of Australia

items.synopsis: The High Court rules a Rohingya man has been unlawfully detained in immigration detention, paving the way to end indefinite detention for other asylum seekers.

title.children: High Court ruling paves way to end indefinite detention for asylum seekers with nowhere to go

image.altText: A horse-like head emerges in gas and dust from a region of space 1,375 light-years from Earth

items.synopsis: The European Space Agency wows with the first full colour images from the Euclid space telescope, a "dark matter detective" with the specs to rival the famed James Webb.

title.children: 'Revolution for astronomy': New space telescope captures mind-blowing images of distant galaxies
